title: Has science ever disproved philosophical theories? - Quora

response.answer_text: There isn’t much in philosophy that can be disproved. Some ideas are no longer popular or haven’t been found to useful or maybe seem hard to reconcile with other things we have learned. Scientists no longer accept mind-body dualism, an idea that had been popular among philosophers for many centuries. The philosopher Descartes is famous for this idea. He did develop logical arguments though the idea probably goes back to Plato and Aristotle.[1] [2] [3]  The exact formulation of this idea has varied over time, but the usual version is that mind and matter are fundamentally different from each other. The mind is somehow immaterial though it may interact with the matter in our body or maybe act in parallel with the matter in our body. Neuroscience and behavioral science hasn’t produced evidence for an immaterial mind. Our thoughts, feelings, dreams, and desires seem to be the product of our brains. There aren’t any experiments showing that we must accept the existence of an immaterial mind. My belief in God is nothing more than neurons firing and releasing neurotransmitters through various regions of the cerebral cortex. In fact, the neurophysiology of religious experience is a perfectly ordinary subdiscipline.[4] [5]Here’s a picture of brain regions activated by prayer.[6]  I understand that most academic philosophers today are now monists; they accept that the mind and body are the same substance and that our mental life is the activity of our brains. Of course, there’s no such thing as proof in philosophy. Some academic philosophers and many ordinary people remain convinced that mind and matter are entirely different substances and that our everyday conscious experience can’t be reduced to the electrical and chemical activity of cells in our heads. The most well preserved ancient theories in philosophy are found in the complete works of Aristotle. In all his works on nature, he considers himself to be doing both science and philosophy. There was no distinction at that point in time. You can see him trying to logically deduce causes from observable phenomena, which is one of the core methods in the empirical sciences. These conclusions are continually revisable because we are continually making new observations, and finding new ways to make new observations, which fit or do not fit our causal explanations. So while the reasoning and logic has essentially stayed the same, I would be surprised to find a single theory in Aristotle’s natural philosophy that has not been sufficiently “disproved”. Throughout the history of natural philosophy since Aristotle, you will find the same pattern of theories being revised or disproved by new observations, especially when we get new technologies which open up the sorts of observations we can make, such as the telescope for astronomy and microscope for biology. In physics, Newton considered himself first and foremost a natural philosopher. It took another natural philosopher, Einstein, to “disprove” in scientific terms, Newton’s theories. The distinctions between natural philosophy and science are so fuzzy that the question amounts to “has science ever disproved a scientific theory?”, or the equivalent, “has natural philosophy ever disproved a theory in natural philosophy?”, or any combination thereof which may sound slightly more meaningful, but essentially mean the same thing. There is really no useful distinction to be made between natural philosophy and science in terms of getting the work done with which they both aim to get done. They aim for the same target: explanation of natural observable phenomena. They use the same methods: observation and inference.

Science is a branch of philosophy: phi·los·o·phy /fəˈläsəfē/ noun. The study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence, especially when considered as an academic discipline. (Google) sci·ence /ˈsīəns/ noun. The intellectual and practical activity encompassing the systematic study of the structure and behaviour of the physical and natural world through observation and experiment. (Google) There is nothing in science that transcends philosophy. The term science is merely a neologism for natural philosophy: Natural philosophy was the common term for the practice of studying nature, from the ancient world to the 19th century. It was in the 19th century that the concept of "science" received its modern shape with new titles emerging such as biology and physics. (Wikipedia) So to answer the question, yes, every time science disproves a theory, it disproves a philosophical theory.

It has, but this is very rarely recognised. The fundamental tenet of falsification, one of the most popular philosophies is that scientific theory cannot be proven, because it is induced from data. But the most important theories of the 20th century can be derived from fundamental principle, Hume’s principle of uniformity in nature, that the fundamental behaviours of matter are always and everywhere the same. Without this principle, there is no science because if the behaviour of matter could change observation would be meaningless. Einstein showed that relativity follows, not from data, but from the way in which we define distances. Von Neumann showed that quantum mechanics follows from the general property that we can give a probabilistic prediction for a measurement result. These theories do indeed disprove the fundamental tenets of falsification.

Philosophy in general is a science. It must be in line with findings from other branches of science. The fact that many philosophers speculate on technical discoveries and some discoveries stimulate philosophies is another problem, but in principle it leads to progress if this interdependence has a common real basis. That is why philosophical theories are often rejected by engineers and philosophers can reject technical theories. The downside is that philosophers and engineers don't really like each other, even though scientists, researchers are more advanced engineers, who also have some philosophy in mind.
